Sure, here's a precise numerical problem related to radioactive decay and half-life equations:

The half-life of a radioactive substance is 10 years. If the initial mass of the substance was 100 grams, what will be the mass of the substance after 30 years?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the radioactive decay formula:

Final mass = Initial mass * (1/2)^(time elapsed / half-life)

In this case, the initial mass is 100 grams, the half-life is 10 years, and the time elapsed is 30 years. Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

Final mass = 100 * (1/2)^(30 / 10)

Final mass = 100 * (1/2)^3

Final mass = 100 * (1/8)

Final mass = 12.5 grams

So, after 30 years, the mass of the radioactive substance will be 12.5 grams.
